1.0  FACILITY ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES

The owners, management, and employees of the AgriSource, Maxwell Facility (herein referred to as AgriSource Maxwell or the Facility) at 5701 Maxwell Road, Maxwell, California 95955 are committed to the prevention of any accidental release of anhydrous ammonia and aqua ammonia. If an accidental release should occur, the Facility is prepared to work with the local fire department, or other authorities to mitigate any release and minimize the impact of the release to people and the environment. A detailed Consolidated Emergency Response/Contingency Plan (CCP) has been developed and will be implemented in the event of an accidental release.



2.0  STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCES HANDLED

*  The Facility is a retail agricultural facility whose primary activity is the storage and sale of fertilizers in addition to the sale of pre-packaged agricultural chemicals to farmers.



*  Anhydrous ammonia is received in bulk and converted to aqua ammonia. These regulated substances are stored, distributed, and dispensed for direct application as crop production nutrients. 



*  Anhydrous ammonia is received by truck and loaded into a 50,000 gallon storage tank (bullet). The regulated substance is later transferred to either one 15,000-gallon storage tank or one 18,000-gallon storage tank. The maximum quantity of anhydrous ammonia handled is 362,627 pounds. The bullets have the following capacities:



Vessel     Vessel Capacity Maximum Volume Amount of NH3 

Bullet 1   15,000 gals        12,750 gals              65,535 lbs

Bullet 2   18,000 gals        15,300 gals              78,642 lbs

Bullet 3   50,000 gals        42,500 gals              218,450 lbs

Totals     83,000 gals        70,550 gals              362,627 lbs



The maximum amount of anhydrous ammonia on site is 362,627 lbs.



*  Aqua ammonia is prepared in a converter by contacting anhydrous ammonia with water (or received by t

ruck). The aqua ammonia is stored in four (4), 66,000-gallon aboveground storage tanks at the site. The four (4) tanks have a nominal shell capacity of 264,000 gallons. 



Vessel    Vessel Capacity    Maximum Volume     Amount of NH4OH 

Tank 1    66,000 gals       66,000 gals                501,600 lbs

Tank 2    66,000 gals       66,000 gals                501,600 lbs

Tank 3    66,000 gals       66,000 gals                501,600 lbs

Tank 4    66,000 gals       66,100 gals                501,600 lbs

Totals     264,000 gals     264,400 gals             2,006,400 lbs



The maximum amount of aqua ammonia on site stored in the tank is 2,006,400 pounds. The amount of ammonia contained within the aqua ammonia solution, if all the tanks were filled to maximum capacity, is 488,400 pounds. 



3.0  GENERAL ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND CHEMICAL SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS

The Facility has implemented the following prevention program elements.



Safety Information:  AgriSource Maxwell ensures that information concerning covered processes and regulated substances are up-to-date and available for review by employees. The most recent review of safety information pertaining to the covered processes took place on June 8, 2018.



Hazard Review:  A hazard review of the regulated processes is conducted every five years or as needed by changes in the processes. The most recent update of the hazard review was conducted February 7, 2018. Results indicated that no high risk hazards were identified through the hazard review update.



Operating Procedures:  Written standard operating procedures have been developed for the covered processes and are reviewed and revised as needed. The operating procedures were last revised in April 17, 2018.



Training:  AgriSource Maxwell staff, as well as Lyman corporate staff, understands that incidents involving the accidental release of regulated substances can be reduced by having trained operations and maintenance staff. A training progra

ompliance audits to assess the effectiveness of the written plan must be conducted every three years. Records of the audits and follow-up documentation are maintained to indicate findings and resolution of findings. In addition to internal compliance audits, the facility is subject to audits by the local Certified Unified Program Agency (CUPA) and Cal/OSHA. The most recent, external compliance audit was conducted by Colusa County Environmental Health On June 14, 2017. 



Incident Investigation:  An incident investigation program is in place at the Facility and incident investigations would be implemented if needed. 



Employee Participation:  The Facility must rely upon the operational expertise and training of its employees at all levels and disciplines to ensure safe operations. The Facility has implemented procedures regarding employee participation to ensure consideration of their knowledge and experience in all applicable areas of the prevention program.



Hot Work Permit:  With regard to hot work that may occur on or near the Anhydrous Ammonia Process, the Facility has developed a written Hot Work Permit to document the evaluation of the fire prevention and protection requirements.



Contractor Safety:  The contractors used by the Facility for anhydrous ammonia delivery have been informed regarding the known potential fire, explosion, or toxic release hazards related to delivery of anhydrous ammonia to the Facility. The Facility has confirmed that the delivery contractors have provided the appropriate training to their drivers regarding the delivery of anhydrous ammonia.



Other Code Applicability:  The Facility implements the provisions of the following guidelines, regulations, and standards for these regulated substances (partial list):

Anhydrous Ammonia 

*  California Code of Regulations, Title 8, Division 1, Chapter 4, Subchapter 1, Unfired Pressure Vessel Safety Orders; 

*  Compressed Gas Association (CGA) Requirements for Storage and Handling of

Anhydrous Ammonia, CGA 2.1-2014 edition [previously American National Standards Institute, Inc. (ANSI) K61.1, 1999 ed.]; and

*  United States Department of Labor, Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA), 29 CFR 1910.111, Storage and Handling of Anhydrous Ammonia.



Anhydrous and Aqua Ammonia

*  American Society of Mechanical Engineers, 31.3 Process Piping; and

*  California Fire Code, Chapter 50, Hazardous Materials



4.0  FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

An incident investigation program is in place at the Facility and incident investigations would be implemented if needed. There have been no accidental releases of anhydrous ammonia or aqua ammonia during the last five years resulting in death, injuries, evacuation, sheltering in place or property or environmental damage.



5.0  THE EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM

The facility's emergency response program is developed in accordance with Section 25503, Division 6.95 of the California Health and Safety Code, Hazardous Materials Business Plan requirements. The Consolidated Emergency Response/Contingency Plan (CCP) was most recently updated in June 2018 and will be implemented in the event of an accidental release of a regulated substance.



6.0  PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY

Safety improvement is an on-going process at the Facility. Periodic evaluations will be performed to assess the maintenance of safe conditions. Specific changes to the anhydrous ammonia and aqua ammonia processes at the Facility will be implemented as needed.



7.0  THE WORST-CASE RELEASE SCENARIO AND ALTERNATIVE RELEASE SCENARIO

The worst-case release scenario and the alternative release scenario were evaluated for each of the regulated processes. The results of the evaluation are provided in the Risk Management Plan (RMP).



Anhydrous Ammonia Worst-Case and Alternative Release Scenarios. 

The worst-case release scenario is the failure of the largest storage tank when filled to the greatest amount, which would release 218,450

pounds of anhydrous ammonia; this represents the volume of the largest storage tank administratively limited at 85% of capacity. The release event assumes a windspeed of 1.5 meters per second (3.4 miles per hour) and a stability class "F" atmosphere (nighttime, light windspeed, no or little cloud cover).



The alternative release scenario based on the hazard review (or a more plausible potential incident) is a release from a broken 4 inch diameter pipe with a wind speed of 3 meters per second (6.7 miles per hour) and stability class "D" modeling parameters.



Aqua Ammonia Worst-Case and Alternative Release Scenarios. 

The worst-case scenario is failure of the largest storage tank when filled to the greatest amount, which would release 501,600 pounds of aqua ammonia (an equivalent of 122,100 pounds of ammonia, NH3) within a secondary containment berm with a net evaporative area of 5,242 square feet. The release event assumes a wind speed of 1.5 meters per second (3.4 miles per hour) and a stability class "F" atmosphere (nighttime, light windspeed, no or little cloud cover).



The alternative release scenario based on the hazard review (or a more plausible potential incident) is a release from a pipe break in the truck loading area. This release scenario has an assumed a wind speed of 3 meters per second (6.7 miles per hour) and stability class "D" modeling parameters.
